headline.main-hed: Lawmakers Sound Alarm Over Wider Internal Surveillance

alt-summary-body.p: Lawmakers voiced concern over the Obama administration's plans for monitoring individuals who hold security clearances as part of a crackdown in the wake of leaks by Edward Snowden.

headline.main-hed: Lawmakers concerned over possible wider surveillance of officials
Lawmakers Concerned Over Wider Internal Surveillance

summary-body.p: Lawmakers voiced concern over the Obama administration's plans for monitoring individuals who hold security clearances as part of a crackdown in the wake of leaks by Edward Snowden.

headline.main-hed: Lawmakers Sound Alarm Over Wider Internal Surveillance
headline.deck: Senators Say Possible Monitoring of Legislative Officials Would Raise Constitutional Questions

article-body.p: WASHINGTON—Lawmakers on Wednesday voiced concern over the Obama administration's plans for monitoring individuals who hold security clearances as part of a crackdown in the wake of leaks by former government contractor Edward Snowden.

Sens. Charles Grassley (R., Iowa) and Ron Wyden (D., Ore.) said in a letter to Director of National Intelligence James Clapper that the stated possibility of "continuous evaluation" of legislative officials would raise constitutional questions and that extensive employee monitoring could inhibit people from coming forward to point out fraudulent or illegal activities. These concerns suggest growing worries among lawmakers about the extent to which the government's monitoring capabilities will be turned on the legislative branch.

"Especially in light of recent events, we first ask that you confirm that you did not intend to suggest that Members of Congress or staff members in the Legislative Branch would be subject to continuous evaluation," the senators wrote.

link.highlight: Poll Shows Erosion in President's Support

list-item.link: Sign Up: Receive the Capital Journal Daybreak newsletter in your inbox

article-body.p: One recent event was the charge by Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D., Calif.) that the Central Intelligence Agencyconducted a "search" of computers that the Senate intelligence committee used for its investigation into the agency's interrogation program, which she said may have violated the constitutional separation of powers and the Fourth Amendment. CIA Director John Brennan responded that any allegations of "hacking into Senate computers" are false. The Justice Department is reviewing the matter.

Messrs. Grassley and Wyden cited testimony by Mr. Clapper in February, in which he said: "We're going to need to change our security clearance process to a system of continuous evaluation." The senators said they want to know whether Mr. Clapper believes the executive branch can continuously evaluate legislative officials with a government security clearance. Messrs. Wyden and Grassley also said the electronic monitoring could undermine protected contacts between federal employees and government investigators.

The senators also raised concerns about monitoring intelligence employees in another part of the same testimony, where Mr. Clapper said that government officials "have a way of monitoring their behavior, both their electronic behavior on the job as well as off the job."

highlight.link: The Letter From Sens. Grassley and Wyden

article-body.p: The two lawmakers said any monitoring would need "safeguards to prevent the chilling of legitimate whistleblower communications and protect the confidentiality of any legally privileged information."

The Senate approved an intelligence bill earlier this month that includes provisions that require the backgrounds of spy-agency employees and contractors to be "monitored on a continual basis." Anticipating that some form of that bill would become law this year, the two lawmakers asked for an explanation of how it would be implemented in a way that wouldn't dissuade potential whistleblowers. They requested a response by July 15.

Eugene Barlow, a spokesman for the office of the National Counterintelligence Executive, a division of the DNI's office, said officials would respond to the concerns. He also pointed to two recent policies enacted by Mr. Clapper to highlight protections established for potential whistleblowers. Neither contains references to monitoring employees for security reasons.
Write to Siobhan Gorman at siobhan.gorman@wsj.com
